Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I gained new insight into the philosophical tradition developed over the past several centuries.
I learned to think carefully about the ways that ideas and arguments are structured, synthesized, and communicated.
I felt like I gained a good grasp of the kind of thinking required of Philosophy and some aspects of philosophy that I might be interested in pursuing in the future. It was a good survey course!
Philosophical analysis, exegesis. How to compare philosophers.
My mind totally expandedI learned how to think better and more logically, also more widely. I also became a better writer.

The syllabus is wonderful as it includes a healthy mix of moral and physical philosophy accurately representing the progress of the timespan it covers. The paper writing is helpful as a means of organizing and expanding upon the ideas in class. I do think the physical philosophy becomes tedious if it is not connected so some real world considerations. Two months of "is this a table?" feels worthless if not situated in the context of their day or ours.
The course is wonderful, but it shouldn't abandon analytic philosophy just as it's starting to get going.
I felt it was a great course, perhaps more guidelines and hand-holding through the semester would have been a good thing. Especially with regards to the expectations of the essays.

It doesn't make that much sense to study the philosophers chronologically as philosophy develops atemporally. For instance, studying areas or schools of thought makes more sense. For example, we could read Plato and Iris Murdoch one week after another and they would be in great dialogue with each other.

I loved the books we read, the lectures were great, and the classroom discussions were also good. The latter could have been improvedI feel like it would have been better for the professor to actually teach us more rather than letting us try to figure everything out on our own. That said, the professor often did do this.
I would recommend DS as a whole to another student, however I think the lack of context and depth of discussion make it the least engaging of the triumvirate.
Yes. Philosophy will make you smarter. Being pummelled repeatedly by so many successive philosophical approaches will make you more resilient.

As with all DS courses, only take if you're an excellent reader. The main thing I took away from this class is an understanding of what's expected in philosophical writing, though I still don't feel competent in it. If you're ready for the work, you might have a fulfilling experience.
Yes. Fanastic course to build foundation in philosophical thought.

I would definitely recommend this courseI feel like more of a human being after having learned from these dead philosophers and my world is so much bigger. Plus, it is a part of DS, which has so far been the highlight of my Yale experience.
